DISCUSSION FMD is one of the most contagious diseases of cloven-hoofed animals. to survive in the host, FMDV has evolved strategies to block IFN expression. previous studies have revealed that FMDV Lpro antagonizes the innate immune responses by inhibiting type I interferon production. poliovirus, rhinovirus type 1a, and encephalomyocarditis virus induce MDA5 degradation. cleavage of a signaling adaptor proximal to the IKK complex has not been reported. NEMO was cleaved by 3Cpro in FMDV-infected porcine cells. the lpaH9.8 protein of Shigella bacteria acts as an E3 ubiquitin ligase to promote polyubiquitination and proteosomal degradation of NEMO. the porcine NEMO protein exhibits a high degree (89%) of sequence conservation. ectopically expressed Flag–RIG-I, Flag-MDA5 and Flag–IPS-1 proteins were reduced in cells coexpressing 3Cpro. however, no cleavage products were observed, suggesting these proteins are unlikely to be proteolytic substrates for FMDV 3Cpro. however, it is impossible to dissect activity of 3Cpro toward NEMO cleavage from that toward inhibiting host protein translation. 3Cpro may dampen host innate immunity by cleaving the translation initiation factor eIF-4A (5) and thereby shutting off host protein synthesis. it will be interesting to investigate whether NEMO cleavage is a shared attribute among 3C proteinases of different picornaviruses.
